description: From Italian fresco, from Medieval Latin friscus, from Frankish *frisk, from Proto-Germanic *friskaz. Doublet of fresh.

nouns.description: fresco (countable and uncountable, plural frescos or frescoes)

entries.meaning: (countable) A cool, refreshing state of the air; coolness, duskiness, shade.
(countable, painting) An artwork made by applying water-based pigment to wet or fresh lime mortar or plaster.
(uncountable, painting) The technique used to make such an artwork.

verbs.description: fresco (third-person singular simple present frescoes, present participle frescoing, simple past and past participle frescoed)
